summary: This is a Bureau of Prisons (BOP) policy document (P6360.01) titled 'Pharmacy Services,' dated January 15, 2005. It outlines comprehensive procedures for pharmaceutical care in federal prisons, covering staffing, operations, formulary management, controlled substance handling, and patient safety protocols. It is a standard operating procedure and contains no direct references to the Epstein case, individuals, or specific events. This document is a Bureau of Prisons (BOP) Program Statement (P6360.01) detailing comprehensive policies and procedures for the management, storage, inventory, dispensing, and administration of controlled substances and other medications within federal correctional institutions. It outlines strict DEA compliance requirements, roles and responsibilities of pharmacy staff, and protocols for preventing and reporting medication errors. This is a Bureau of Prisons (BOP) policy document (P6360.01) detailing comprehensive procedures for medication management, error reporting, adverse drug reactions, and specific protocols for controlled substances like methadone. It outlines responsibilities for prescribers, pharmacists, and other staff to ensure safe medication use within federal correctional institutions.

connections.description: The Chief Pharmacist sends a memo to the HSA with a copy to the Warden regarding theft or loss of controlled substances. The Warden then notifies the DEA.
The institutional Chief Pharmacist submits quarterly controlled substance inventory reports to the BOP Chief Pharmacist.
The Chief Pharmacist sends documentation of controlled substance theft or loss to the Health Services Administrator (HSA) for review.
The HSA designates, in writing, a Health Services supervisor as the Chair of the Quarterly Controlled Substances Inventory Team.

This is a detailed BOP policy (P6360.01) from 2005 governing every aspect of controlled substance management in federal prisons, highlighting an institutional focus on strict DEA compliance.

The policy mandates a biennial inventory of all controlled substances and a quarterly audit by a designated team, with the Chief Pharmacist acting only as a technical advisor, not a team member, suggesting checks and balances.
Procedures for the 'pill line' are explicitly detailed, requiring direct observation of ingestion, checking for 'cheeking,' and using two forms of inmate ID to prevent diversion.
The document outlines extensive contingency plans for pharmacist absence, including contracts, interagency agreements, and using PHS officers, indicating the critical role of pharmacist oversight.
It establishes a formal, blame-free Medication Error Program focused on system improvement, categorizing errors per American Society of Health Systems Pharmacists guidelines.
This is a standard BOP medication management policy (P6360.01) dated January 15, 2005, signed by Director Harley G. Lappin.

The document establishes detailed protocols for medication dispensing, error reporting (with a severity rating scale from Level 0 to Level 6), and adverse drug reaction monitoring within federal prisons.
It specifies strict controls for needles, syringes, and controlled substances, requiring secure storage and detailed inventory tracking.
The policy outlines specific, regulated uses for methadone within BOP institutions: treatment of opiate-addicted pregnant inmates, detoxification, and treatment of severe pain.
The document contains no direct references to Jeffrey Epstein, his associates, victims, or any events related to his case; it is purely a procedural guideline for prison healthcare operations.
